articles.headline: For Trump, Three Decades of Chasing Deals in Russia
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump, and eventually his children, repeatedly sought business in Russia as far back as 1987, in a variety of ventures. But none got off the ground.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump, and eventually his children, repeatedly sought business in Russia as far back as 1987, in a variety of ventures. But none got off the ground.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was 2005, and Felix Sater, a Russian immigrant, was back in Moscow pursuing an ambitious plan to build a Trump tower on the site of an old pencil factory along the Moscow River that would offer hotel rooms, condominiums and commercial office space.
articles.byline: By Megan Twohey and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Voice of Politics in Nevada Media Starts a News Website
articles.snippet: Jon Ralston, a journalist known for his confrontational style, is starting The Nevada Independent, saying he sees an appetite for more sources of news.
articles.abstract: Jon Ralston, a journalist known for his confrontational style, is starting The Nevada Independent, saying he sees an appetite for more sources of news.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the months after Sheldon Adelson, a casino magnate and prominent Republican donor, purchased The Las Vegas Review-Journal in late 2015, one local journalist was particularly relentless in criticizing the new ownership.
articles.byline: By Timothy Pratt and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: As Trump Era Arrives, a Sense of Uncertainty Grips the World
articles.snippet: Having made contradictory comments, President-elect Donald J. Trump has many nations wondering about his policies. But there’s also a sense that his words should not be taken too literally.
articles.abstract: Having made contradictory comments, President-elect Donald J. Trump has many nations wondering about his policies. But there’s also a sense that his words should not be taken too literally.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Germans are angry. The Chinese are downright furious. Leaders of NATO are nervous, while their counterparts at the European Union are alarmed.

articles.headline: A Rare Corner of Finance Where Women Dominate
articles.snippet: Women hold the top positions in corporate governance at many of the biggest mutual funds and pension funds — deciding which way to vote on the directors of a company board.
articles.abstract: Women hold the top positions in corporate governance at many of the biggest mutual funds and pension funds — deciding which way to vote on the directors of a company board.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once a year, a small group of executives who control trillions of dollars in American companies meet for lunch in Manhattan. Among the things they discuss: pushing for greater say in how companies are run.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Leslie Picker

articles.headline: As Support for E.U. Flags Elsewhere, Bulgaria Sees Its Benefits
articles.snippet: While much of Europe has complained about the European Union, Bulgarians paint a different picture, with the Balkan country viewing the bloc as a major positive.
articles.abstract: While much of Europe has complained about the European Union, Bulgarians paint a different picture, with the Balkan country viewing the bloc as a major positive.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — With Bulgaria in the grips of a bank run in the summer of 2014, Lyubomir Vassilev was panicking.

articles.headline: In ‘Brexit’ Speech, Theresa May Outlines Clean Break for U.K.
articles.snippet: In long-awaited remarks, the British prime minister emphasized regaining control of immigration, even if it means losing E.U. trading advantages.
articles.abstract: In long-awaited remarks, the British prime minister emphasized regaining control of immigration, even if it means losing E.U. trading advantages.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Presidents Have Less Power Over the Economy Than You Might Think
articles.snippet: We associate presidents with eras — and eras with strong or weak economies. But the reality is more complicated.
articles.abstract: We associate presidents with eras — and eras with strong or weak economies. But the reality is more complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Presidential reputations rise or fall with gross domestic product. The state of the economy can determine if presidents are re-elected, and it shapes historical memory of their success or failure.

articles.headline: New York Times Study Calls for Rapid Change in Newsroom
articles.snippet: Among the broad recommendations of an internal report are increasing training and hiring for digital roles and reducing the layers of editing.
articles.abstract: Among the broad recommendations of an internal report are increasing training and hiring for digital roles and reducing the layers of editing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Times has deftly adapted to the demands of digital journalism, but it needs to change even more quickly, according to an internal report that recommends the company expand training for reporters and editors, hire journalists with more varied skills and deepen engagement with readers as a way to build loyalty and attract the subscriptions necessary to survive.
